title: Bailey's Beach, Newport, R.I.

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on canvas.

description: Childe Hassam, like other American Impressionists of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, recorded scenes of leisure and recreation, especially country vacation retreats. This painting portrays fashionable Bailey’s Beach in Newport, Rhode Island, an exclusive seaside town known at the time for its wealth and luxury. Hassam depicted sand dunes rising from behind the beach with the promenade and its costumed bathers at a distance, reinforcing the fact that he, and the viewer, are excluded from this privileged setting. The artist’s Impressionist strategies—including the use of scintillating colors, energetic brushwork, and a light palette—capture the vibrant atmosphere of this sunny resort.
inscriptions:
Signed lower left: Childe Hassam 1901

On back: c.1901
publication_history: Judith A. Barter et al., The Age of American Impressionism: Masterpieces from the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago/Yale University Press, 2011), no. 65.
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, A Century of Progress, June 1–Nov. 1, 1934, no. 449. San Francisco, De Young Memorial Art Museum, Exhibtiion of American Painting, June 7–July 7, 1935, no. 120. Pittsburgh, Carnegie Institute, Survey of American Painting, Oct. 24–Dec. 15, 1940, no. 180. Milwaukee–Downer College, Wisconsin, A Century of Landscape Painting by American Artists, 1851–1951, Feb. 13 – Mar. 23, 1951, cat. no. 10. *only checklist on back of symposium brochure, The Arts in Society, Milwaukee–Downer College Feb. 13, 1951. Davenport Municipal Art Gallery, Sports and Recreation Panorama, Apr. 4–May 4, 1959, no. 44. Museum of Art, Rhode Island School of Design, Providence, The Eden of America: Rhode Island Landscapes, 1820–1920, Jan. 24–Apr. 27, 1986. Brussels, United States Embassy, Whitlock Hall, Art in Embassies Exhibition, May 15, 2019–Dec. 13, 2020, no cat. no.
provenance_text: The artist, 1901. Macbeth Galleries, New York, by 1917. Sold to Duncan Phillips (1886–1966), Washington, DC, 1917. Sold to Knoedler Gallery, New York, February 18, 1929. To Milch Galleries, New York, by 1933. Sold to Paul Schulze, Chicago, 1936; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1936.
